source.73dc428a:
import pandas as pd
import numpy as np
import warnings
warnings.filterwarnings('ignore')
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
import plotly.graph_objs as go
import plotly.offline as py
import plotly.express as px
import operator
from plotly.subplots import make_subplots
source.c967ca4a:
data = pd.read_csv('/kaggle/input/kaggle-survey-2020/kaggle_survey_2020_responses.csv')
questions = data.iloc[0, :].T
data = data.iloc[1:, :]

data.rename({'Q1':'AGE GROUP'}, axis = 1, inplace = True) 
data.rename({'Q2':'GENDER'}, axis = 1, inplace = True)
data.rename({'Q3':'COUNTRY'}, axis = 1, inplace = True)
data.rename({'Q4':'EDUCATION'}, axis = 1, inplace = True)
data.rename({'Q5':'TITLE'}, axis = 1, inplace = True)
data.rename({'Q6':'CODING EXP'}, axis = 1, inplace = True)
data.rename({'Q8':'1ST LANG'}, axis = 1, inplace = True)

idata = data[data['COUNTRY'] == 'India']
imale = idata[idata['GENDER'] == 'Man']
ifemale = idata[idata['GENDER'] == 'Woman']
source.2246abc8:
country_wise_distribution = data['COUNTRY'].value_counts()
fig = px.choropleth(country_wise_distribution.values, locations = country_wise_distribution.index,
                    locationmode = 'country names',
                    color = country_wise_distribution.values,
                    labels={'color':'Count', 'locations':'Location'},
                    color_continuous_scale = px.colors.sequential.OrRd)
fig.update_layout(title = "COUNTRYWISE DISTRIBUTION")
fig.show()
source.b7e973ef:
fig = px.histogram(data, y="COUNTRY", histnorm='percent',template="plotly_dark")
fig.update_layout(xaxis={"ticksuffix":"%"})
fig.update_layout(xaxis_title="COUNT PERCENTAGE")
fig.update_traces(marker_color='rgb(255,128,128)', marker_line_color='rgb(255,128,128)',
                  marker_line_width=1.5, opacity=1)
fig.show()
source.939bb3db:
counts = data['GENDER'].value_counts(sort=True)
labels = counts.index
values = counts.values
o_pie = go.Pie(labels=labels, values=values, name="Overall", hole=.3, domain={'x': [0,0.46]},
               marker=dict(colors=px.colors.qualitative.Pastel1))

icounts = idata['GENDER'].value_counts(sort=True)
ilabels = icounts.index
ivalues = icounts.values
i_pie = go.Pie(labels=ilabels, values=ivalues, name="India", hole=.3,domain={'x': [0.52,1]},
               marker=dict(colors=px.colors.qualitative.Pastel1))

layout = dict(title = 'GENDER DISTRIBUTION', font=dict(size=12), legend=dict(orientation="h"),
              annotations = [dict(x=0.17, y=0.5, text='Overall', showarrow=False, font=dict(size=20)),
                             dict(x=0.8, y=0.5, text='India', showarrow=False, font=dict(size=20)) ],template="plotly_dark")

fig = dict(data=[o_pie, i_pie], layout=layout)
py.iplot(fig)
source.a300a5c7:
labels=[ '18-21',
         '22-24',
         '25-29',
         '30-34',
         '35-39',
         '40-44',
         '45-49',
         '50-54',
         '55-59',
         '60-69',
         '70+' ]
o_values = data['AGE GROUP'].value_counts(sort=True).values
o_pie = go.Pie(labels=labels, values=o_values, name="Overall", hole=.3,domain={'x': [0,0.46]}, marker=dict(colors=px.colors.qualitative.Pastel1+px.colors.qualitative.Pastel2))
i_values = idata['AGE GROUP'].value_counts(sort=True).values
i_pie = go.Pie(labels=labels, values=i_values, name="India", hole=.3,domain={'x': [0.52,1]}, marker=dict(colors=px.colors.qualitative.Pastel1+px.colors.qualitative.Pastel2))

layout = dict(title = 'AGE GROUPWISE DISTRIBUTION', font=dict(size=10), legend=dict(orientation="h"),
              annotations = [dict(x=0.17, y=0.5, text='Overall', showarrow=False, font=dict(size=20)),
                             dict(x=0.8, y=0.5, text='India', showarrow=False, font=dict(size=20)) ],template="plotly_dark")

fig = dict(data=[o_pie, i_pie], layout=layout)
py.iplot(fig)

source.855fdc36:
count_male = imale['EDUCATION'].value_counts().reset_index()
count_female = ifemale['EDUCATION'].value_counts().reset_index()

pie_men = go.Pie(labels=count_male['index'],values=count_male['EDUCATION'],name="Men",hole=0.4,domain={'x': [0,0.46]}, marker=dict(colors=px.colors.qualitative.Pastel1+px.colors.qualitative.Pastel2))

pie_women = go.Pie(labels=count_female['index'],values=count_female['EDUCATION'],name="Women",hole=0.5,domain={'x': [0.52,1]}, marker=dict(colors=px.colors.qualitative.Pastel1+px.colors.qualitative.Pastel2))

layout = dict(title = 'GENDERWISE HIGHER EDUCATION - INDIA', font=dict(size=12), legend=dict(orientation="h"),
              annotations = [dict(x=0.19, y=0.5, text='Men', showarrow=False, font=dict(size=20)),
                             dict(x=0.81, y=0.5, text='Women', showarrow=False, font=dict(size=20)) ],template="plotly_dark")

fig = dict(data=[pie_men, pie_women], layout=layout)
py.iplot(fig)

idata['TITLE']=idata['TITLE'].fillna("Not Mentioned")
fig = px.histogram(idata, y="CODING EXP", color="TITLE",color_discrete_sequence=px.colors.qualitative.Pastel,
    template="plotly_dark")
fig.update_layout(yaxis_title="Programming Experience")
fig.update_layout(title = "TITLE WISE PROGRAMMING EXPERIENCE - INDIA")
fig.show()
source.d95e57a9:
q7 = [
    'Q7_Part_1', 'Q7_Part_2', 'Q7_Part_3', 'Q7_Part_4', 
    'Q7_Part_5', 'Q7_Part_6', 'Q7_Part_7', 'Q7_Part_8', 
    'Q7_Part_9', 'Q7_Part_10', 'Q7_Part_11', 
    'Q7_Part_12', 'Q7_OTHER'
]

ds = idata['Q7_Part_1'].value_counts().reset_index()
ds.columns = [
    'Programming Language', 
    'Users'
]

for i in range(1, len(q7)):
    term = idata[q7[i]].value_counts().reset_index()
    term.columns = [
        'Programming Language', 
        'Users'
    ]
    ds = pd.concat([ds, term])

ds = ds.sort_values(['Users'])

fig = px.bar(
    ds, 
    x='Users', 
    y="Programming Language", 
    orientation='h', 
    title='PREFERRED PROGRAMMING LANGUAGE - INDIA', 
    width=800,
    height=500,
    color = 'Programming Language',
    color_discrete_sequence=px.colors.qualitative.Pastel,
    template="plotly_dark"
)

fig.show()
source.47fd6721:
idf = idata[q7].fillna('No')
idf = idf.replace({'Python':'Yes','R':'Yes','SQL':'Yes','C':'Yes','C++':'Yes','Java':'Yes','Javascript':'Yes','Julia':'Yes','Swift':'Yes','Bash':'Yes','MATLAB':'Yes','None':'Yes','Other':'Yes'})

fig = px.parallel_categories(idf, labels={'Q7_Part_1':'Python', 'Q7_Part_2':'R', 'Q7_Part_3':'SQL', 'Q7_Part_4':'C', 
    'Q7_Part_5':'C++', 'Q7_Part_6':'Java', 'Q7_Part_7':'Javascript', 'Q7_Part_8':'Julia', 
    'Q7_Part_9':'Swift', 'Q7_Part_10':'Bash', 'Q7_Part_11':'MATLAB', 
    'Q7_Part_12':'None', 'Q7_OTHER':'Other'}, template="plotly_dark")

fig.show()

ds = idata['Q15'].value_counts().reset_index()
ds.columns = [
    'Experience', 
    'Count'
]

ds = ds.sort_values(['Count'])

fig = go.Figure()
fig.add_trace(go.Scatter(
    x=ds['Experience'],
    y=ds['Count'],
    marker=dict(color="crimson", size=15),
    mode="markers",
    name="Count",
))


fig.update_layout(title='NUMER OF YEARS USING ML METHODS - INDIA',
                  xaxis_title='Experience',
                  yaxis_title="Count")

fig.show()

    specs=[[{"type": "xy"},{"type": "domain"}]],
)

fig.add_trace(go.Bar(x=x, y=y, name='India'),
              row=1, col=1)
fig.add_trace(go.Pie(labels=x,values=y, name='India'),
              row=1, col=2)
fig.update_layout(height=500, showlegend=False,template="plotly_dark")
fig.update_layout(title = "PREFERRED LEARNING PLATFORM - INDIA")
fig.show()
source.012a62c1:
ds = idata['Q38'].value_counts().reset_index()
ds.columns = [
    'Tool', 
    'Count'
]

ds = ds.sort_values(['Count'])
fig = go.Figure()

fig.add_trace(go.Scatterpolar(
      r=ds['Count'],
      theta=ds['Tool'],
      fill='toself',
      name = 'Count',
      #fillcolor='violet', 
      line=dict(color='violet'),
      showlegend=True, 
      #opacity=0.6
))

fig.update_layout(
  polar=dict(
    radialaxis=dict(
      visible=True,
      range=[0,max(ds['Count'])]
    )),
  showlegend=False,
    title='PREFERRED DATA ANALYSIS TOOLS - INDIA'
)

fig.show()
source.a90e3686:
m={}
idata.rename({'Q39_OTHER':'Q39_Part_12'}, axis = 1, inplace = True)
for i in range(11):
    value=idata['Q39_Part_'+str(i+1)].value_counts().values[0]
    text=idata['Q39_Part_'+str(i+1)].value_counts().index[0]
    m[text]=value
m=dict(sorted(m.items(), key=operator.itemgetter(1)))

x=list(m.keys())
y=list(m.values())

fig = make_subplots(
    rows=2, cols=2,
    specs=[[{"type": "xy"},{"type": "domain"}],[{"type": "domain"},{"type": "domain"}]],
)


fig.add_trace(go.Bar(x=x, y=y, name='India'),
              row=1, col=1)
fig.add_trace(go.Pie(labels=x,values=y, name='India'),
              row=2, col=2)
fig.update_layout(height=800, showlegend=False,template="plotly_dark")
fig.update_layout(title = "FAVOURITE MEDIA SOURCES - INDIA")
fig.show()

source.d16d55db:
2020 Kaggle ML & DS Survey - INDIA

Overview
source.03b9fa4d: **MySQL** is most frequently used big data product in India.
source.c685c836: Mostly none of the automated machine learning tools (or partial AutoML tools) are used on a regular basis. **Automated model selection (auto-sklearn, xcessiv)** is most popular among rest.
source.2a396b7a: ML/Cloud Computing Services Budget
source.830e6467: Most of the Indian respondants have been using ML methods for less than a year time period.
source.209f98fa: Local development environments (RStudio, JupterLab, etc) followed by Basic statistical softwares (Microsofy Excel, Google Sheets, etc) are mostly used as primary tools at work or school to analyze data in India.
source.ba417662: Most Indian Kagglers recommend learning **Python** to aspiring data scientists as their first programming language.
source.98543f62: We can see that **scikit-learn** framework is most used on a regular basis in India followed by **TensorFlow** and **Keras**.
source.8aa85ea7: We can see that **Linear/Logistic Regression** is most used followed by **Decision Trees/Random Forest** and **CNNs** on a regular basis in India.
source.dc238d79: Preferred Sharing Platform
source.e86985db: Most of the Indian Kagglers hope to become more familiar with **AWS** followed by **GCP** and **Microsoft Azure** in the next 2 years.
source.43c0f9d9: In India, the company size of maximum number of respondents where they are employed is 0-49 employees followed by 10,000 or more employees.
source.f346032e: Most of the Indian respondents or their team haven't spent any money on machine learning and/or cloud computing services at home (or at work) in the past 5 years.

In India, 54.7% of male respondents have Bachelor's degree as highest level of formal education attained (or plan to attain within the next 2 years) which is greater than percentage of female respondents (46.9%) who have the same degree.
Whereas, 30.8% of male respondents have Master's degree as highest level of formal education attained or plan to attain within the next 2 years which is less than percentage of female respondents (37.4%) who have the same degree.
source.c4568259: In India, maximum respondents have 20+ individuals who are responsible for data science workloads at their place of business.
source.4e848ca5: We can see that overall there is quite large gender gap. In India 22% women participated in the survey which is greater than the overall women participation percentage (19.4%).
